title: Brexit: Boris Johnson under pressure to break 'do-or-die' by Halloween pledge
text:

Boris Johnson is under pressure to break his “do or die” pledge to leave the European Union on October 31 as the two sides struggle to strike a deal.

Brexit negotiations will go down to the wire on Wednesday with Brussels and the UK still trying to thrash out a compromise on the controversial Irish border issue.

But the Prime Minister was warned that another Brexit delay might be needed to finally get a deal to go through.

Finnish leader Antti Rine, who hold the EU’s rotating presidency, said negotiations could continue after the crunch summit of EU leaders later this week.

He said: “I think there is no time in a practical or legal way to find an agreement before the EU Council meeting. We need more time.”

Irish Foreign Minister Simon Coveney said a deal was possible but that much more work was needed.

(Image: REUTERS)

“A deal is possible, and it’s possible this month, may even be possible this week. But we’re not there yet,” he said. “There’s still a lot of work to do, so I hope that we can make more progress today.”

It raises the possibility of an emergency EU summit at the end of the month to finally approve any 11th hour deal.

At the State Opening of Parliament, the Queen’s Speech stopped short of repeating Mr Johnson’s explicit promise to leave the EU on Halloween come what may.

Mr Johnson faces a major Commons showdown when he returns to Westminster after the summit for an emergency Saturday sitting of Parliament, the first since the Falklands War.

If he fails to get a deal, he is expected to ask MPs to vote on a no deal Brexit . Opposition MPs could also attempt to table a vote on a second referendum.

(Image: JESSICA TAYLOR/UK PARLIAMENT HANDOUT/EPA-EFE/REX)

But No 10 said Mr Johnson would not resign if MPs voted down the Queen’s Speech next week - and could even plough on and introduce the bills regardless.

Talks are continuing in Brussels but time is rapidly running out if there is to be a deal to put to leaders to sign off at their crunch summit later this week.

There are also concerns that any deal would not get through Parliament - and if it did, that there would not be enough time to get the laws through before the deadline.

Rebel ex-Tory Nick Boles said: “MPs will want to scrutinise the legislation that implements our withdrawal very closely and ensure that an extension is secured if there is any chance that this legislation will not have completed its passage before October 31.”

But No 10 ruled out extending Brexit by a couple of weeks if a deal looked in sight - even if just for a technical extension.

(Image: PA)

“I’m generally not aware such a thing even exists. The PM is clear that we leave on October 31st,” the PM’s official spokesman said.

No 10 claimed there would be enough time to get a deal through Parliament.

“The public would expect Parliament to work round the clock in order to pass that legislation to leave on October 31,” he said.

Mr Johnson is believed to have proposed a customs plan that would see Northern Ireland treated differently to the rest of the UK, as well as an assurance that no one community could have a veto.

But the PM risked being boxed in by his DUP allies who warned they would “not be eating our own words” over their opposition to the province staying tied to the EU - as Commons leader Jacob Rees-Mogg has suggested he may have to do.

European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker suggested the EU would agree to another delay.

“It’s up to the Brits to decide if they will ask for an extension,” he said.

“But if Boris Johnson were to ask for extra time — which probably he won’t — I would consider it unhistoric to refuse such a request.”
description: Negotiations are set to go down to the wire - with the UK and Brussels still trying to thrash out a compromise on Northern Ireland
